questions.text: Fingerprints are discovered by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sir William J. Herschel Sir William J. Herschel, a British civil servant in colonial India, was instrumental in recognizing the uniqueness and permanence of fingerprints. In 1859, he began requiring Indian civil servants to sign contracts with their fingerprints, acknowledging their individuality and permanence. This practice laid the groundwork for the use of fingerprints in personal identification. Incorrect Responses: B. Sir Francis Galton: While Sir Francis Galton, a British anthropologist and cousin of Charles Darwin, made significant contributions to the study of fingerprints, including publishing a comprehensive book on the subject in 1892, he did not discover fingerprints. His work built upon the foundational observations made by Herschel. C. Sir Edward Henry: Sir Edward Henry, a British police official, developed the Henry Classification System for fingerprints, which became widely adopted for criminal identification. However, he did not discover fingerprints; his work was based on the earlier findings of Herschel and Galton. D. Sir Edmund Locard: Sir Edmund Locard was a French criminologist known for formulating Locard's Exchange Principle, which states that the perpetrator of a crime will bring something into the crime scene and leave with something from it, and that both can be used as forensic evidence. He did not discover fingerprints.

questions.text: True about female pseudohermaphroditism
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Male form of external genitalia There are two types of pseudo-hermaphroditism: a) Male pseudo-hermaphroditism • Nuclear sex is XY • There is presence of testis in the abdomen or inguinal canal, but the external genitalia is of female form. • Characterized by female external genitalia, primary amenorrhea, normal sized breasts, scanty or absent axillary or pubic hair, due to testicular feminization. • 5-a reductase deficiency occurs. b) Female pseudo-hermaphroditism • Nuclear sex is XX • External genitalia are male form due to adrenal hyperplasia. • 21 hydroxylase deficiency is most common

questions.text: Finger printing finder involves recording prints of 8 fingers. Which finger pair is excluded?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Little finger • Fingerprint reader (FINDER), is a computerized automatic fingerprint reading system which can record each fingerprint data in half a second. • Prints of 8 fingers are recorded except little finger.

questions.text: Chilotic line is used to determine
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sex • Chilotic line is an anthropometric line extending from the posterior aspect of the ilio-pectineal eminence to the closest point on the anterior auricular margin (the pelvic segment) and then to the iliac crest (the sacral portion). • The pelvic segment is predominant in females and the sacral segment is predominant in males. • Thus, chilotic index may be used in forensic practice to identify the sex of human skeletal remains, although studies suggest its reliability is limited.

questions.text: Stature is measured by one of the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Trotter and Glesser’s Formula • Stature from long bones can be estimated by measuring the length of long bones and by using regression formulae, such as: - Jit and Sing formula, - Trotter and Glesser’s formula, - Karl-Pearson’s formula, - McKern & Steele’s formula, - Dupertuis and Hadden’s formula etc. • Haase’s rule is used to estimate the gestational age of a foetus. • Gustaffson’s method is used to estimate the age of a person by secondary changes in the teeth. • Rule of 12 is for rigor mortis.

questions.text: Best method of determine age up to 14 years is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dentition • The age of a child up to 12-14 years can better be determined by the study of eruption of temporary and permanent teeth. • The study of appearance and fusion of ossification centres help to estimate the age up to 21 years. • Head circumference helps to estimate the age of a foetus. • Anthropometry is used to identify an adult person by the descriptive data, body moles/scars and body measurements.

questions.text: Fusion of xiphoid process occurs at
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 40 years • The four pieces of the body of sternum start fusing from below upwards. • The 4th piece fuses with 3rd piece at the age of 15 years, the 3rd piece fuses with 2nd piece at the age of 20 years and the 2nd piece fuses with the 1st piece at the age of 25 years. • The xiphisternum fuses with body at the age of 40 years. The manubrium fuses with body at an old age.

questions.text: Second common pattern of finger printing is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Whorls In fingerprint analysis, the primary patterns are loops, whorls, and arches. Among these, loops are the most common, followed by whorls, and then arches. Composite patterns, which are combinations of these basic patterns, are less common and not typically considered a primary category. Whorls are the second most common fingerprint pattern, characterized by circular or spiral ridge formations. They are present in approximately 30–35% of fingerprints. Incorrect Responses: A. Loops: Loops are the most common fingerprint pattern, found in about 60–65% of fingerprints. B. Arches: Arches are the least common primary fingerprint pattern, present in about 5% of fingerprints. D. Composite: Composite patterns are combinations of the basic patterns and are less common. They are not typically considered a primary category in fingerprint classification.

questions.text: Stain used for detection of ‘ Y ’ chromosomes is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Quinacrine dihydrochloride The detection of the Y chromosome, which is specific to males, can be achieved through various staining techniques. Among the options provided, quinacrine dihydrochloride is a fluorescent dye that binds to DNA and exhibits a strong fluorescence when bound to the Y chromosome, making it effective for identifying male cells. Quinacrine dihydrochloride is a fluorescent dye that binds to DNA and exhibits strong fluorescence when bound to the Y chromosome, making it effective for identifying male cells. Incorrect Responses: A. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH): While FISH is a powerful technique for detecting specific DNA sequences, it requires the use of labeled probes complementary to the target DNA. It is not a staining method but a hybridization technique. C. Feulgen reaction: The Feulgen reaction is a histochemical method for detecting DNA by hydrolyzing DNA to produce a red color. It does not specifically identify the Y chromosome. D. Acriflavine Schiff reagent: Acriflavine is a fluorescent dye used for staining nucleic acids, and Schiff reagent is used in histology for staining carbohydrates. Neither is specific for detecting the Y chromosome.

choices.text: System of personal identification using the body measurement

questions.text: Edmund Locard is known for his
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Theory of exchange • Jit & Sing, Trotter & Glesser, Karl-Pearson, McKern & Steele and Dupertuis & Hadden are known for formula for estimation of stature. • Sir Edmond Locard is known for Theory of exchange, (i.e. whenever two objects come in contact with each other always there is transference of material from one object to the other) and also known for Poroscopy (i.e. Locard’s method – Identification of a person by the study of the mouths of the ducts of sweat glands in the ridges of fingers). • Sir Alphonso Bertillon is known for System of personal identification using the body measurement, body marks and body description. • Sir William J Herschel, Sir Francis Galton and Sir Edward Henry are known or dactylography.

questions.text: Lower end of the femur can be help to determine the
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Age • Ossification centre for lower end of femur appears at 9th month of intra-uterine life and fuses with the shaft at 18-19 years in males and 17-18 years in females (one year earlier than males), which helps in determination of age of a person. • Stature/Height of a person can be determined by the entire femur. • However weight cannot be determined by the femur.

questions.text: Ossification centre appearing at birth is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Upper end of tibia • Ossification centre for upper end of humerus appears at ½ to 1 year. • Ossification centre for scaphoid appears at 4-5 years. • Ossification centre for lower end of femur appears at 9th month of intra-uterine life. • The ossification centre for the upper end of tibia appears at birth. • The other ossification centres appear at birth are, 4th piece of the body of the sternum and cuboid.

questions.text: Which area of skull is prominent in female
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Parietal In human skull anatomy, certain features exhibit sexual dimorphism, meaning they differ between males and females. Among the options provided, the parietal region is generally more prominent in females. In females, the parietal bones often have a more rounded and less pronounced contour compared to males. This results in a smoother and more rounded appearance of the skull's sides and top. The parietal eminences, which are the bulging areas on the sides of the skull, are typically less pronounced in females, contributing to a more rounded cranial vault. Incorrect Responses: B. Occipital: The occipital region, located at the back of the skull, is generally more pronounced in males. Features such as the external occipital protuberance (the bump at the back of the head) are more prominent in males, contributing to a more angular appearance. C. Temporal: The temporal bones, located on the sides of the skull, do not exhibit significant sexual dimorphism in terms of prominence. Both males and females have similar temporal bone structures, though overall skull robustness may differ. D. Supraorbital ridge: The supraorbital ridge, or brow ridge, is typically more pronounced in males. In females, this ridge is less prominent, contributing to a smoother forehead appearance.

questions.text: Closure of coronal sutures starts at age of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The coronal sutures are the joints between the frontal bone and the two parietal bones of the skull. These sutures do not close at birth—in fact, they remain open well into adulthood and begin to close (fuse) gradually with age. The closure of coronal sutures typically begins around the age of 30 to 35 years. The process is slow and variable and may not be complete until later in life (sometimes even 50+ years). Therefore, the age range 30–35 years marks the beginning of closure, making Option C the correct answer.

questions.text: Pre-auricular sulcus helps in detection of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sex • The sex determination from the skeletal remains can be done only after puberty, except in case of greater sciatic notch where sex can be determined even in a foetus. • In case of hip bone, sex can be determined from the greater sciatic notch (narrow and deep in males and wide and shallow in females), shape of the body of the pubis (triangular in males and quadrangular in females), and pre-auricular sulcus, which is not prominent (sometimes not even visible), narrow & shallow in males, and more frequent, broad and deep in females • Best criteria in pelvis to determine sex is Sciatic notch index. • Pre-Auricular Sulcus is a Tertiary sexual characteristic.

questions.text: Best specimen of bone for sex determination is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pelvis According to Krogman, percentage of accuracy in determination of sex from bones is as follows: • Entire skeleton -100% • Pelvis + Skull - 98% • Pelvis alone - 95% • Skull alone - 90% • Only long Bones - 80%

questions.text: The fingerprint pattern may be impaired permanently in cases of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Leprosy • Permanent impairment of fingerprints can occur in: - Leprosy, Charring, Radiation, Electrical injuries, and Corrosives. • Ridge alteration take place in: - Eczema, acanthosis nigricans, scleroderma, dry and atrophic skin. • Temporarily modification is seen in: - Coeliac disease. • Change in the distance between ridges but without change in pattern is seen in: - Rickets and acromegaly.

questions.text: Corporo-basal index is useful for determination of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sex • Corporo-basal index : Length of Body of S1/Length of Base of Sacrum x 100. • In Males, it is 45 and in females it is 40 • Other indices to differentiate sex from bones are: • Sternal index, 1. Ischio-pubic index (Washburn index), 2. Sciatic notch index, 3. Sacral Index and 4. Medullary Index.

questions.text: Identical twins will not have same
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fingerprint pattern Identical twins, or monozygotic twins, originate from a single fertilized egg that splits into two embryos, resulting in individuals with nearly identical genetic material. Despite this genetic similarity, certain physical characteristics can differ due to environmental factors during fetal development. Fingerprints are formed during fetal development and are influenced by both genetic and environmental factors. While identical twins share the same genetic makeup, their fingerprints are not identical. Each twin's unique intrauterine environment leads to subtle differences in the formation of their fingerprints, making them distinct from one another. Incorrect Responses: B. DNA fingerprint pattern: Identical twins have the same DNA fingerprint pattern because they share identical genetic material. DNA fingerprinting analyzes unique DNA sequences, and since identical twins have the same DNA, their DNA fingerprints are indistinguishable. C. HLA system: The Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) system is a part of the immune system, and identical twins have the same HLA markers due to their identical genetic makeup. This similarity is crucial for organ transplantation compatibility between identical twins. D. Blood group: Blood groups are determined by specific genes, and since identical twins share the same genetic material, they have the same blood type. This genetic similarity extends to other inherited traits as well.

questions.text: ‘Crural index’ helps to differentiate
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Race The following indices help to differentiate race from bones: 1. Cephalic Index: Maximum transverse breadth of skull / Maximum anteroposterior length of skull × 100 2. Brachial Index: Length of Radius/Length of Humerus × 100 3. Crural Index: Length of Tibia/Length of Femur × 100 4. Humero-Femoral Index (Intra-membral index): Length of Humerus/Length of Femur × 100 5. Inter-membral index : (Length of Humerus + Length of Radius)/( Length of Femur + Length of Tibia) x 100

questions.text: The most reliable bones for the purpose of medullary index are the following except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sternum • Medullary Index is used to differentiate the sex. • Medullary index = Diameter of Medulla / Diameter of Whole bone x 100. • Ideal bones for Medullary index are: Tibia, Humerus, Radius, Ulna. • Medullary index is also used to differentiate human hair from animal hair; i.e., Diameter of Medulla / Diameter of Whole bone x 100.

questions.text: The parameters used in Bertillon system are all EXCEPT
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Finger prints Bertillon system or Anthropometry (Portrate Parle) is an Anthropometric system based on the physical measurement of specified parts of body, even if there are no biological Specimens. Three important criteria of this system is 1) Descriptive data: Includes full description of a person such as complexion, colour of the hair, colour of the iris, shape of the nose, lips, chin, etc. 2) Body marks: Such as moles, birth marks, scars, etc. 3) Body measurements: 11 in number, namely, 1. Standing height 2. Sitting height 3. Length of the head 4. Breadth of the head 5. Breadth of the face 6. Distance between two outstretched upper limbs 7. Length of left forearm and hand 8. Length of left middle finger 9. Length of left little finger 10. Length of left foot and 11. Length of right ear

questions.text: The parameter used to enlarge the photo to life size for superimposition in Ruxton’s case is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Tiara • Superimposition is a technique in identifying a person by superimposing the X-ray of skull found after death on the photo of the face of the suspected person. • This was first applied by Glaister and Brash in 1935 in Isabella Ruxton’s case. • The ‘TIARA’ was used to enlarge the photo to life size. • A negative result having more credibility because it can definitely be stated that the skull and the photograph are not those of the same person.

questions.text: Number of Ossification centers at birth are
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 450 At birth, the human skeleton consists of approximately 450 ossification centers. These centers are regions where bone formation occurs, and they eventually fuse to form the 206 bones present in the adult human skeleton. The process of ossification continues throughout childhood and adolescence, leading to the consolidation of these bones.

questions.text: Height of a child at the age of 1 year is about
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 68 cm At 12 months, the average height for boys is about 75.7 cm (29.75 inches), and for girls, it's approximately 74 cm (29 inches). These figures are derived from growth charts developed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) The height of a child: - At full term is about 50 cm. - At 6 months is about 60cm. - At 1 year is about 68cm. and - At 4 years is between 90 and 100cm (Twice the birth height).

questions.text: The commonest heart defect in Turner’s syndrome is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bicuspid aortic valve Turner’s syndrome is characterized by 3 principal features: 1. Short stature. 2. Congenital anomalies like web neck, shield chest, wide-set nipples, cubitus valgus, bicuspid aortic valve (Most common heart defect – 30%), coarctation of aorta (5-10%), septal defect, aortic dissection, osteoporosis, renal abnormalities, red green colour blindness, pigmented navei, short 4th metatarsal, dyslexia, high-arched palate, low-set ears, spina bifida, low posterior hairline, etc. 3. Sexual infantilism: primary amenorrhoea, sterility, grossly undeveloped breast, scanty pubic & axillary hair, infantile vagina, infantile fallopian tubes and ovaries containing fibrous tissue without ovarian follicles (streak ovaries)

questions.text: Early tooth eruption is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Syphilis • Early tooth eruption is seen in Syphilis, may be at birth. • Delayed tooth eruption is seen in; - Hypothyroidism (Commonest cause), - Hypopituitarism, - Rickets, - Down’s syndrome, - Cleidocranial dysplasia, - Cysts and - Supernumerary teeth.

questions.text: The method of age estimation by height and weight of teeth is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Stack’s method • Mile’s method: This is used by studying only the root transparency of a tooth after the age of 30 years. • Boyde’s method: Cross striations in the enamel and dentine of deciduous teeth and permanent first molars represent daily incremental lines. Studied by histological sections. The age of an individual can be calculated by counting the number of lines from neonatal line onwards. Neonatal line is considered as an indicator of birth. This method is applicable mainly to infants. The age so calculated is accurate with an error of around 20 days. • Stack’s method: Estimation of the age of infants from the weight and height of the erupting teeth of child. It is used on both deciduous and permanent during their erupting phase. Lamendil’s method: Estimation of age from using only 2 criteria namely, gingival recession and root transparency.

questions.text: Up to how long after death can fluorescent dyes demonstrate Y chromosomes in the dental pulp in badly decomposed bodies?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 12 months Fluorescent dyes can effectively detect Y chromosomes in dental pulp tissue up to 12 months after death, even in cases of significant decomposition. This extended detection period is due to the robust nature of teeth, which can preserve DNA for extended periods, allowing for gender determination in severely decomposed bodies. Studies have demonstrated that Y-chromosome detection in dental pulp remains feasible up to 12 months post-mortem, even in badly decomposed bodies. This is attributed to the protective environment of the dental pulp, which can preserve DNA integrity longer than other tissues.

questions.text: The ideal method to recognize latent tattoo in living is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ultra violet light • Latent tattoos are invisible tattoo marks which can be made visible by ultraviolet rays. • Infrared photography makes old tattoos readily visible • Regional lymph node biopsy: Previous application of tattoo mark (Latent tattoo) can be determined in a dead body where there will be presence of dye. • Laser: Is the best method to remove tattoo.

choices.text: Upper end of radius and ulna
Lower end of radius and ulna

questions.text: Age of a 15 year old female is best determined by the radiograph of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Upper end of radius and ulna • The ossification centers fuse about 1 year earlier in females than males. • Upper ends of radius and ulna fuse at the age of 16-17 years in males (In females it fuses at 15-16 years). • In males, lower end of Ulna fuses at 17-18 years, lower end of Radius fuses at 18-19 Years, upper end of femur fuses at 17-18 years and upper end of humerus fuses at 18-19 years.

questions.text: Femur is ----------- % of the individual’ height
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 27 The femur, also known as the thigh bone, is the longest and strongest bone in the human body. Studies in anatomy and anthropometry have shown that the length of the femur typically constitutes about 27% of an individual's total height. This proportion is consistent across most individuals and is a reliable measure used in forensic science and anthropological studies to estimate height from skeletal remains. The reason for this relationship is that the femur plays a significant role in supporting the body’s structure and determining overall height due to its length and position in the lower limb. Incorrect Options: A. 20% This value underestimates the proportion of the femur to the total height. While some bones in the body, such as the humerus or radius, might make up a smaller percentage of height, the femur’s length is greater due to its crucial role in weight-bearing and mobility. Therefore, this percentage is too low to accurately represent the femur’s contribution to height. B. 22% Although closer to the correct value than 20%, this option is still an underestimate. The femur consistently accounts for a slightly larger proportion (around 27%) of an individual’s height, as determined through anthropometric studies and anatomical standards. D. 35% This value overestimates the femur’s proportion relative to total height. While the femur is the longest bone, 35% is unrealistically high and would imply a body structure where the legs are disproportionately long compared to the rest of the body. This value exceeds the observed anatomical norms.

questions.text: Subpubic angle in females is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The subpubic angle is the angle formed by the pubic bones at the pubic symphysis. In females, this angle is typically 90º to 100º. This wider angle is an important anatomical adaptation for childbirth, providing a broader pelvic outlet to accommodate the passage of the baby during delivery. The female pelvis, compared to the male pelvis, is generally broader and has a more open shape, with a wider subpubic angle being one of its defining characteristics. This range of 90º to 100º ensures optimal functionality for reproductive purposes without compromising structural support. Incorrect Options: A. 110º An angle greater than 110º would significantly exceed the normal anatomical range for the female subpubic angle. This would indicate an unusually wide pelvis, which is atypical and not supported by standard anthropometric measurements.

choices.text: Immediately after death, the body may shorten by about 2-3 cm
Immediately after death, the body may lengthen by about 2-3 cm
Change in stature after death occurs only when the deceased was engaged in struggle at the time of death
There is absolutely no change in stature after death

questions.text: Which of the following facts regarding the stature of the body is correct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Immediately after death, the body may lengthen by about 2-3 cm • In a dead body, soon after death due to primary relaxation of the muscles, the body length may be more by 2–2.5 cm. • Later, when rigor mortis develops, it may be shortened. • With the passage of rigor mortis and onset of putrefaction, the length may change due to secondary relaxation. • The height varies in the various hours of the day, being maximum in the morning and less by 1.5 to 2 cm in the evening due to reduction of elasticity of intervertebral discs.

questions.text: Stain used for tattooing are all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Osmium dye. Osmium dye is not used for tattooing because it is not suitable for injecting into the skin. Osmium compounds are primarily used in scientific applications, such as staining biological tissues for electron microscopy, and are not designed for use in tattooing. These dyes lack the properties needed for long-lasting, safe, and stable pigmentation in the skin. Additionally, osmium compounds can be toxic, making them inappropriate for body art. Incorrect Options: A. Indian ink Indian ink, also known as India ink, is commonly used in tattooing. It contains carbon black particles that are finely dispersed in a liquid, making it suitable for creating clear and lasting designs on the skin. Its safety and stability make it a popular choice for tattoos, especially in traditional practices. B. Vermillion Vermillion is a red pigment derived from mercury sulfide. While its use is less common today due to concerns about mercury toxicity, it has historically been used in tattooing for its vibrant red color. Despite its potential health risks, it was once a standard pigment in tattooing. D. Prussian blue Prussian blue, a deep blue pigment made from iron compounds, has been used in tattooing to create blue designs. It is a stable pigment that provides a vibrant blue color, making it suitable for tattoos. Its durability and rich hue make it a popular choice for blue ink.

choices.text: Increase in the size of penis
Increase in the size of testis

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest secondary sexual character to develop in males?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Increase in the size of testis Tanner’s sexual maturity rating Genitals (male) Tanner I • Testicular volume less than 1.5 ml; • Small penis of 3 cm or less (prepubertal) (typically age 9 and younger) Tanner II • Testicular volume between 1.6 and 6 ml; skin on scrotum thins, reddens and enlarges; • Penis length unchanged (9–11) Tanner III • Testicular volume between 6 and 12 ml; scrotum enlarges further; • Penis begins to lengthen to about 6 cm (11–12.5) Tanner IV • Testicular volume between 12 and 20 ml; scrotum enlarges further and darkens; • Penis increases in length to 10 cm (12.5–14) Tanner V • Testicular volume greater than 20 ml; adult scrotum; • Penis of 15 cm in length (14+) Pubic hair (both male and female) Tanner I • No pubic hair at all (prepubertal) (typically age 10 and younger) Tanner II • Small amount of long, downy hair with slight pigmentation at the base of the penis and scrotum (males) or on the labia majora (females) (10–11.5) Tanner III • Hair becomes more coarse and curly, and begins to extend laterally (11.5–13) Tanner IV • Adult–like hair quality, extending across pubis but sparing medial thighs (13–15) Tanner V • Hair extends to medial surface of the thighs (15+) BREASTS (FEMALE) Tanner I • No glandular tissue; areola follows the skin contours of the chest (prepubertal) (typically age 10 and younger) Tanner II • Breast bud forms, with small area of surrounding glandular tissue; areola begins to widen (10–11.5) Tanner III • Breast begins to become more elevated, and extends beyond the borders of the areola, which continues to widen but remains in contour with surrounding breast (11.5–13) Tanner IV • Increased breast size and elevation; areola and papilla form a secondary mound projecting from the contour of the surrounding breast (13–15) Tanner V • Breast reaches final adult size; areola returns to contour of the surrounding breast, with a projecting central papilla. (15+)
